Subkey: To COOKE OPTICS LIMITED for their continuing innovation in the design
column6: development and manufacture of advanced camera lenses that have helped define the look of motion pictures over the last century. Since their first series of motion picture lenses

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: JAMES JACOBS and DR. RICHARD DORLING for the development of the Tissue Physically-Based Character Simulation Framework. This framework faithfully and robustly simulates the effects of anatomical structures underlying a character’s skin. The resulting dynamic and secondary motions provide a new level of realism to computer-generated creatures. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: ALLAN JAENICKE
column7: JOHN-PAUL SMITH and ROSS SHAIN for the creation of the Mocha planar tracking and rotoscoping software at Imagineer Systems Ltd. Mocha provides robust planar-tracking even when there are no clearly defined points in the image. Its effectiveness
column8: ease of use
column9: and ability to exchange rotoscoping data with other image processing tools have resulted in widespread adoption of the software in the visual effects industry. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: WILLIAM FREDERICK and JIM MARKLAND of Anton/Bauer
column7: Inc. for the design and creation of the CINE VCLX Portable Power System. The CINE VCLX provides extended run-times and flexibility
column8: allowing users to power cameras and other supplementary equipment required for production. This high-capacity battery system is also matched to the high-demand
column9: always-on digital cinema cameras. [Systems]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: MATT CORDNER and NICKSON FONG for the invention and publication of the Pose Space Deformation technique. Pose Space Deformation (PSD) introduced the use of novel sparse data interpolation techniques to the task of shape interpolation. The controllability and ease of achieving artistic intent have led to PSD being a foundational technique in the creation of computer-generated characters. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)

column8: final-quality interactive render preview
column9: scalable architecture and powerful user-configurable spreadsheet interface. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: BRIAN HALL and JEREMY SELAN for the creation of the Katana computer graphics scene management and lighting software at Sony Pictures Imageworks. Katana’s unique design
column7: featuring a deferred evaluation procedural node-graph
column8: provides a highly efficient lighting and rendering workflow. It allows artists to non-destructively edit scenes too complex to fit into computer memory
column9: at scales ranging from a single object up to an entire detailed city. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Subkey: To DAVID M. LAUR for the development of the Alfred render queue management system. This system was the first robust

column9: scalable approach to render queue management. Queue was one of the first systems that allowed for statistical analysis and process introspection

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To FLORIAN KAINZ for the design and development of the robust
column6: highly scalable distributed architecture of the ObaQ render queue management system. ObaQ has scaled from managing a few hundred processors in 1997 to many thousands today

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: MICHAEL BUNNELL and CHRISTOPHE HERY for the development of point-based rendering for indirect illumination and ambient occlusion. Much faster than previous ray-traced methods
column7: this computer graphics technique has enabled color bleeding effects and realistic shadows for complex scenes in motion pictures. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To DR. RICHARD KIRK for the overall design and development of the Truelight real-time 3D look-up table hardware device and color management software. Through the use of color management software and hardware
column6: this complete system enables accurate color presentation in the digital intermediate preview process. The Truelight system is widely utilized in digital intermediate production environments around the world. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: MARKUS HASENZAHL
column7: DR. KLAUS ANDERLE and ANDREAS LOEW for the development of the Spirit 4K/2K film scanning system as used in the digital intermediate process for motion pictures. The Spirit 4K/2K has distinguished itself by incorporating a continuous-motion transport mechanism enabling full-range
column8: high-resolution scanning at much higher frame rates than non-continuous transport scanners. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: DR. REIMAR LENZ and BERND BRAUNER for the development of the ARRISCAN film scanner
column7: enabling high-resolution
column8: high-dynamic range
column9: pin-registered film scanning for use in the digital intermediate process. The ARRISCAN film scanner utilizes a specially designed CMOS array sensor mounted on a micro-positioning platform and a custom LED light source. Capture of the film’s full dynamic range at various scan resolutions is implemented through sub-pixel offsets of the sensor along with multiple exposures of each frame. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: THEO BROWN
column7: TONY SEDIVY and DR. JOHN QUARTEL for the development of the Northlight film scanner
column8: which enables high-resolution
column9: pin-registered scanning in the motion picture digital intermediate process. Developed for the digital intermediate and motion picture visual effects markets
column10: the Northlight scanner was designed with a 6K CCD sensor
column11: making it unique in its ability to produce high-resolution scans of 35mm

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: MARTIN TLASKAL
column7: DARRIN SMART and DR. JAMES LOGIE for their contributions to the development of the Baselight color correction system
column8: which enables real-time digital manipulation of motion picture imagery during the digital intermediate process. Baselight was one of the first digital color correction systems to enter the digital intermediate market and has seen wide acceptance in the motion picture industry. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: GYULA PRISKIN and TAMAS PERLAKI for their contributions to the development of the Lustre color correction system
column7: which enables real-time digital manipulation of motion picture imagery during the digital intermediate process. Lustre is a software solution that enables non-linear
column8: real-time digital color grading across an entire feature film
column9: emulating the photochemical color-timing process. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: D. SCOTT DEWALD
column7: BILL WERNER and GREG PETTITT for their contributions furthering the design and refinement of the Texas Instruments DLP Projector technology
column8: achieving a level of performance that enabled color-accurate digital intermediate previews of motion pictures. Working in conjunction with the film industry
column9: Texas Instruments created a high-resolution
column10: color-accurate
column11: high-quality digital intermediate projection system that could closely emulate film-based projection in a theatrical environment. [Projection]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: RYOJI NISHIMURA
column7: MASAAKI MIKI and YOUICHI HOSOYA for the design and development of Fujicolor ETERNA-RDI digital intermediate film
column8: which was designed exclusively to reproduce motion picture digital masters. The Fujicolor ETERNA-RDI Type 8511/4511 digital intermediate film has thinner emulsion layers with extremely efficient couplers made possible by Super-Nano Cubic Grain Technology. This invention allows improved color sensitivity with the ability to absorb scattered light
column9: providing extremely sharp images. The ETERNA-RDI emulsion technology also achieves less color cross-talk for exacting reproduction. Its expanded latitude and linearity provides superior highlights and shadows in a film stock with exceptional latent image stability. [Film]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: TIM HAWKINS
column7: JOHN MONOS and DR. MARK SAGAR for the design and engineering of the Light Stage capture devices and the image-based facial rendering system developed for character relighting in motion pictures. The combination of these systems
column8: with their ability to capture high fidelity reflectance data of human subjects
column9: allows for the creation of photorealistic digital faces as they would appear in any lighting condition. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To MARK WOLFORTH and TONY SEDIVY for their contributions to the development of the Truelight real-time 3D look-up table hardware system. Through the use of color management software and hardware
column6: this complete system enables accurate color presentation in the digital intermediate preview process. The Truelight system is widely utilized in digital intermediate production environments around the world. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: CHRISTIAN BAEKER and FRANK BILLASCH for their contributions to the LUTher 3D look-up table hardware device and color management software. The LUTher system was one of the first color look-up table processors to be widely adopted by the pioneering digital intermediate facilities in the industry. This innovation enabled accurate color presentation by facilities that had analyzed projected film output and built 3D look-up tables in order to emulate print film. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: KEVIN WOOLEY
column7: BRETT ALLEN and COLIN DAVIDSON for the development of the Imocap on-set performance capture system. Developed at Industrial Light & Magic and consisting of custom hardware and software
column8: Imocap is an innovative system that successfully addresses the need for on-set
column9: low-impact performance capture. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: KEN McGAUGH and HILMAR KOCH for advancing the technique of ambient occlusion rendering. Ambient occlusion has enabled a new level of realism in synthesized imagery and has become a standard tool for computer graphics lighting in motion pictures. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To BJÖRN HEDÉN for the design and mechanical engineering of the silent
column6: two-stage planetary friction drive Hedén Lens Motors. Solving a series of problems with one integrated mechanism
column7: this device had an immediate and significant impact on the motion picture industry. [Photography]"

in recognition of his leadership and efforts toward identifying and solving the problem of High-Speed Emulsion Stress Syndrome in motion picture film stock. Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Academy Award of Merit)
Subkey: To the EASTMAN KODAK COMPANY for the development of photographic emulsion technologies incorporated into the Kodak Vision2 family of color negative films. These new technologies are breakthroughs in film speed
column6: grain and sharpness that have made a significant impact on the motion picture industry. The Vision2 family allows wider use of high-speed color negative film
column7: lower light levels on set and faster set-ups. Most importantly
column8: Vision2 improves the overall picture quality in theatrical presentation. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: NAFEES BIN ZAFAR and RYO SAKAGUCHI for the development of the fluid simulation system at Digital Domain. This influential and flexible production-proven system incorporates innovative algorithms and refined adaptations of published methods to achieve large-scale water effects. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: RON FEDKIW and FRANK LOSASSO PETTERSON for the development of the Industrial Light & Magic fluid simulation system. This production-proven simulation system achieves large-scale water effects within ILM’s Zeno framework. It includes integrating particle level sets
column7: parallel computation
column8: and tools that enable the artistic direction of the results. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To CHRISTIEN TINSLEY for the creation of the transfer techniques for creating and applying 2D and 3D makeup known as ‘Tinsley Transfers.’ These techniques allow quick and precisely repeatable application of 2D makeup such as tattoos
column6: bruises and birthmarks
column7: as well as 3D prosthetic appliances ranging in size from small wounds to entire torsos. They utilize self-adhesive material that features an unprecedented combination of tissue-thin edges
column8: resilience
column9: flexibility and water resistance
column10: while requiring no dangerous solvents. [Systems]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To JÖRG PÖHLER and RÜDIGER KLEINKE of OTTEC Technology GmbH for the design and development of the battery-operated series of fog machines known as ‘Tiny Foggers.’ The operating characteristics of this compact
column6: well-engineered and remote-controllable package make possible a range of safe special effects that would be totally impractical with larger
column7: more conventional fog units. [Stage Operations]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To SEBASTIAN CRAMER for the invention and general design
column6: and ANDREAS DASSER
column7: head of development at P&S Technik GmbH
column8: for the mechanical design
column9: of the Skater Dolly and its family of products. This small
column10: portable
column11: camera-only dolly allows low lens positions
column12: movement in restricted places and tight offset circular maneuvers with rapid set-up. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: IGNACIO VARGAS and ANGEL TENA for the creation of the RealFlow software application. RealFlow was the first widely adopted
column7: commercially available
column8: easy-to-use system for the simulation of realistic liquids in motion picture visual effects. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: DR. JERRY TESSENDORF
column7: DR. JEROEN MOLEMAKER and MICHAEL KOWALSKI for the development of the system of fluid dynamics tools at Rhythm & Hues. This system allows artists to create realistic animation of liquids and gases using novel simulation techniques for accuracy and speed
column8: as well as a unique scripting language for working with volumetric data. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: JOS STAM
column7: JULIA PAKALNS and MARTIN WERNER for the design and implementation of the Maya Fluid Effects system. This system is used to create simulations of gaseous phenomena integrated into the widely available Maya tool suite
column8: using an unconditionally stable semi-Lagrangian solver. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: THOMAS GANSHORN and OLIVER PILARSKI for the development of the Flowline fluid effects system. Flowline is a flexible system that incorporates highly parallel computation
column7: allowing rapid iteration and resulting in detailed
column8: realistic fluid effects. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: JIM HOUSTON
column7: DENIS LECONTE and CHRIS BUSHMAN of Pacific Title and Art Studio for the design and development of the Rosetta process for creating digital YCM archival masters for digital film restoration. With elements that may be recombined either digitally or optically
column8: the Rosetta Separations process offers a uniquely great versatility in achieving high-quality results for digital YCM archiving. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: COLIN DAVIDSON
column7: MAX CHEN and FRANCESCO CALLARI for the design and development of the ILM Image-based Modeling System. This highly integrated system facilitates interactive construction and editing of 3D models from digital photographs and addresses the three-dimensional scanning needs of motion pictures in unique and innovative ways. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: SIMON ROBINSON
column7: BEN KENT and DR. ANIL KOKARAM for the design and development of the Furnace integrated suite of software tools that robustly utilizes temporal coherence for enhancing visual effects in motion picture sequences. The Furnace toolset’s modularity
column8: flexibility and robustness has set a high standard of quality for optical flow-based image manipulation. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To HOWARD PRESTON and MIRKO KOVACEVIC for the design and engineering of the Preston Cinema Systems FI+Z wireless remote system. Pioneering unprecedented reliability and flexibility in wireless lens and camera operation
column6: the FI+Z has continued to be a leader in innovation since its introduction in 1994. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To JOSHUA PINES and CHRIS KUTCKA of Technicolor Digital Intermediates for the design and development of the TDI process for creating archival separations from digital image data. The TDI process is based on the production of digital separation negatives creating archival elements that can be scanned and digitally recombined in the future. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To WILLIAM FEIGHTNER and CHRIS EDWARDS of E-Film for the design and development of the E-Film process for creating archival separations from digital image data. The E-Film process is based on the production of digital separation negatives creating archival elements that can be scanned and digitally recombined in the future. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: PAPKEN SHAHBAZIAN
column7: RONALD BELKNAP and JAY McGARRIGLE for the design and development of the Hollywood Film Company Brumagic MPST Densitometer. The Brumagic MPST was designed specifically to measure density in the motion picture soundtrack and has become the densitometer of choice for reading soundtrack negative and positive densities worldwide. [Sound]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: JOSEF HANDLER
column7: THOMAS SMIDEK and MARC SHIPMAN MUELLER for the design and development of the Arriflex 235 Camera System. Designed for handheld photography
column8: the features of this small
column9: lightweight MOS camera also allow it to be used as a secondary production camera. [Camera]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To FLORIAN KAINZ for the design and engineering of OpenEXR
column6: a software package implementing 16-bit
column7: floating point
column8: high dynamic range image files. Widely adopted
column9: OpenEXR is engineered to meet the requirements of the visual effects industry by providing for lossless and lossy compression of tiered and tiled images. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To WALTER TRAUNINGER and ERNST TSCHIDA for the design and engineering of the Arri WRC wireless remote lens control system. This highly modular system permits accurate and reliable wireless control with multiple hand controls of all lens functions. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To CHRISTIAN TSCHIDA and MARTIN WAITZ of cmotion for the design and engineering of the cmotion Wireless Remote System. The graphical user interface of the cmotion System eases the difficult task of following focus
column6: and the unique lens tag system recalls the calibration for each lens. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To PETER LITWINOWICZ and PIERRE JASMIN for the design and development of the RE:Vision Effects family of software tools for optical flow-based image manipulation. A unique user interface and relatively low cost have made these tools ubiquitous in the visual effects community. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: JOHN A. BONNER MEDAL OF COMMENDATION

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To DAVID GROBER for the concept and mechanical design and SCOTT LEWALLEN for the electronic and software design of the Perfect Horizon camera stabilization head. Perfect Horizon effectively neutralizes the extraneous motion encountered in boats
column6: camera cars
column7: snowmobiles or other vehicles
column8: leaving the pan/tilt head and camera stable and level with the horizon. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: YURIY POPOVSKY and OLEKSIY ZOLOTAROV for the concept and development of the Russian Arm gyro-stabilized camera crane and the Flight Head. The Russian Arm and Flight Head opened new possibilities for filmmakers. With the ability to be mounted on the roof of almost any car
column7: this remotely-operated crane and camera head can move smoothly in a 360 degree circle around the car
column8: even while it is being driven at high speeds by actors
column9: creating heretofore impossible perspectives. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To ANATOLIY KOKUSH for the concept and development of the Cascade series of motion picture cranes. The lightweight structure of the Cascade and Traveling Cascade Cranes enables the filmmaker to achieve heights of up to 70 feet
column6: allowing for the placement of the camera in otherwise impossible locations. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To GARRETT BROWN for the original concept of the Skycam flying camera system – the first use of 3-D volumetric cable technology for motion picture cinematography. In creating the first remote-controlled
column6: cable-supported flying camera system
column7: Garrett Brown’s pioneering efforts have influenced all subsequent development in this area of technology. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: MICHAEL KASS and ANDREW WITKIN for their pioneering work in physically-based computer-generated techniques used to simulate realistic cloth in motion pictures. Their 1998 paper titled “Large Steps in Cloth Simulation” was a seminal work
column7: providing the key in demonstrating to the industry that the calculations necessary to simulate realistic
column8: complex cloth could be achieved efficiently and robustly. Their work provided the conceptual foundation for many cloth simulation systems in use today. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: PETER HANNAN and RICHARD LONCRAINE for the development of the remote camera head known as the Hot-Head. In use for over a quarter of a century
column7: the Hot-Head has brought the possibility of safe
column8: remotely-operated shots to every filmmaker. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To GARY THIELTGES for the design and development of the remotely-operated
column6: lightweight camera head known as the Sparrow Head. This well-integrated remote system enables filmmakers to remotely pan and tilt their camera from virtually any moving vehicle
column7: giving the opportunity for unprecedented dynamic camera angles. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To FRANK FLETCHER and DAVE SHERWIN for the introduction and continuing development of the Power Pod modular camera head system. The Power Pod system enables filmmakers to configure a remote controlled head to meet their own unique requirements. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: MICHAEL SORENSEN and J. WALT ADAMCZYK for the design and development of the Aerohead motion control camera head and the J-Viz Pre-Visualization system. This remote head not only serves the needs of the live-action filmmaker
column7: but also provides the functionality of a motion-controlled head
column8: allowing for sophisticated tiling and pre-visualization techniques. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To SCOTT LEVA for the design and development of the Precision Stunt Airbag for motion picture stunt falls. The Precision Stunt Airbag is designed to envelop the stunt jumper
column6: even on off-center hits. This feature serves to enhance the safety of stunt performers in falls from up to 200 feet. [Stage Operations]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: GEORGE PETERS and VASILIY ORLOV for the development of the Ultimate Arm Camera Crane System for specialized vehicle photography. Representing a significant evolutionary improvement in camera car technology
column7: this remotely-controlled
column8: gyro-stabilized and flexible camera crane offers a highly stable platform for high-speed
column9: rough terrain action shots. Its ingenious applications of sophisticated technology solve many of the problems inherent in chase vehicle filming. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: ALEX MacDONALD and MARK CHAPMAN for the development of the Cablecam 3-D volumetric suspended cable camera technologies. The evolution of the Cablecam technology has made it possible to move a camera safely and accurately anywhere through a three-dimensional space. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: BEN BRITTEN SMITH and MATT DAVIS for the development of the Spydercam 3-D volumetric suspended cable camera technologies. The evolution of the Spydercam technology has made it possible to move a camera safely and accurately anywhere through a three-dimensional space. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To JOHN PLATT and DEMETRI TERZOPOULOS for their pioneering work in physically-based computer-generated techniques used to simulate realistic cloth in motion pictures. Their 1987 paper “Elastically Deformable Models” was a milestone in computer graphics
column6: introducing the concept of physically-based techniques to simulate moving
column7: deforming objects. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: for the original concept
column7: and TONY DeROSE and JOS STAM for their scientific and practical implementation of subdivision surfaces as a modeling technique in motion picture production. Subdivision surfaces have become a preferred modeling primitive for many types of motion picture computer graphics. [Digital Imaging Technology]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: TERRY CLABORN
column7: STEVE GARLICK
column8: BILL HOGUE and TIM REYNOLDS for the design
column9: engineering and implementation of the Technicolor Real Time Answer Print System. This system provides a method by which filmmakers can preview real-time color corrections using actual film prints
column10: reducing both the turnaround time and the number of reprints required. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To UDO SCHAUSS and HILDEGARD EBBESMEIER for the optical design and NICOLE WEMKEN and MICHAEL ANDERER for the mechanical design of the Cinelux Premiere Cinema Projection Lenses. The Cinelux Premiere Lenses incorporate an iris and aspheric elements which provide a more uniform modulation transfer function and better light transmission to the sides and corners of the theater projection screen. This reduces the traditional problems of softness in the corners
column6: hot-spotting and varying brightness between film formats. [Projection]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)

column7: allowing noise attenuation with fewer artifacts. [Sound]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To DR. CHRISTOPHER HICKS and DAVE BETTS for the design and implementation of the Cedar DNS 1000 multi-band digital noise suppressor. column6: the autonomous agent animation system used for the battle sequences in The Lord of the Rings trilogy. In ‘The Lord of the Rings’ trilogy
column7: over 200

column6: an underwater camera housing system for use in motion pictures. The Remote AquaCam brings to the industry an underwater camera housing specifically designed for remote and high-speed operation. Its hydro-dynamic shape facilitates ease of operation for surface hand-held filming

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: HANS LEISINGER and GEORGE JOHN ROWLAND of Deluxe Laboratories for the concept and design of the Deluxe High Speed Spray Film Cleaner. This innovative and effective high speed film cleaning machine is unique in its use of spray technology
column7: providing the flexibility to use alternative solvents
column8: and to anticipate changes in environmental legislation. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: and ARRI USA
column7: INC. for the concept and engineering of the Arriflex 435 Camera System. The 435 enhances the creative process via its programmability and reliability
column8: and provides the camera operator with the widest feature and performance capability of any MOS camera in use today. [Camera]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To ARNOLD & RICHTER CINE TECHNIK and the CARL ZEISS COMPANY for the concept and optical design of the Carl Zeiss/Arriflex Variable Prime Lenses. This series of variable prine lenses opens many creative possibilities
column6: since any focal length can be continuously selected throughout the entire range. They offer sharp
column7: high-contrast
column8: high-resolution images with minimized vignetting
column9: superior to many prime lenses. [Lenses and Filters]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To DEREK C. LIGHTBODY of OpTex for the design and development of Aurasoft Luminaires. The Aurasoft offers a radical new type of reflector design for the production of soft
column6: very even and relatively shadowless light
column7: with superior coverage and significantly higher intensity than existing softlights. [Lighting]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: RONAN CARROLL
column7: ASSAFF RAWNER
column8: PAUL BARTLETT and SIMON WAKLEY for the creation of the Milo Motion-Control Crane. This radically original and effective solution to the problems of high-speed camera motion was achieved with the combination of novel geometry and dedicated 3-dimensional control software. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To MICHAEL SORENSEN and RICHARD ALEXANDER of Sorensen Designs International
column6: and DONALD TRUMBULL for advancing the state-of-the-art of real-time motion-control
column7: as exemplified in the Gazelle and Zebra camera dolly systems. Over the past decade
column8: Sorensen
column9: Alexander and Trumbull have improved the speed
column10: repeatability and portability of robotic camera platforms through novel engineering concepts and the pioneering use of composite materials. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
column6: THOMAS F. POWERS and FRED M. FUSS of the Eastman Kodak Company for the design and development of KeyKode latent-image barcode key numbers. KeyKode numbers are machine-readable bar codes on camera negative films that exactly replicate the human-readable key numbers. Together with an appropriate reader and database software
column7: they reduce errors and speed important post-production operations
column8: leading to significant cost savings. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Scientific and Engineering Award)
Subkey: To IAIN NEIL for the optical design; TAKUO MIYAGISHIMA for the mechanical design; and PANAVISION
column6: INCORPORATED
column7: for the concept and development of the Primo Series of spherical prime lenses for 35mm cinematography. The Primo Series of lenses for 35mm cinematography represents a thorough and comprehensive approach to prime lens design
column8: development and manufacture. This family of lenses has a wide range of focal lengths
column9: all color matched
column10: with improved modulation transfer function characteristics. [Lenses and Filters]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To GARRETT BROWN and JERRY HOLWAY for the creation of the Skyman flying platform for Steadicam operators. This cable-driven
column6: manned camera platform allows the operator to spin 360 degrees for unimpeded pans while controlling the downhill speed via brakes. As a device for achieving otherwise impossible shots
column7: Skyman has had a definite influence on later cable-suspended camera systems. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: JAMES WEBBER and BOB WEBBER of Cablecam Systems
column7: and TROU BAYLISS for the design and engineering of Cablecam. This radio-controlled
column8: cable-driven camera platform with its ultra-smooth synthetic cables and powerful hydraulic motors
column9: enables runs in excess of 3000 feet with quick return to start. Operating unmanned
column10: it can function at speeds and through perils that would be unsafe for on-board operators. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: BALA S. MANIAN and THOMAS L. NOGGLE for their pioneering efforts in the development of laser film recording technology. This pioneering laser film recorder
column7: designed and used for motion pictures
column8: demonstrated the potential of this technology for recording digital data onto intermediate film stock. [Special Photographic]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: MIKE BOLLES
column7: UDO PAMPEL and JOSEPH FULMER of Industrial Light & Magic for their pioneering work in motion-controlled
column8: silent camera dollies. This silent
column9: high-speed motion control modification of a Panther dolly makes it possible to film moving camera composite shots of actors while recording live dialogue. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: BILL SCHULTZ
column7: CHRIS BARKER and DAVID CORNELIUS of Sony Pictures Imageworks for the creation of an advanced motion-controlled
column8: silent camera dolly. This extensive modification to the Panther dolly allows high-speed moves to be silent
column9: smooth and stable. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To BRUCE WILTON and CARLOS ICINKOFF of Mechanical Concepts for their modular system of motion-control rotators and movers for use in motion-control. These components have become the de facto industry standard for use in precision motion control equipment. [Camera Cranes]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To REMY SMITH for the software and electronic design and development; and JAMES K. BRANCH and NASIR J. ZAIDI for the design and development of the Spectra Professional IV-A digital exposure meter. The design and execution of the Spectra Professional IV-A meter has resulted in a practical and successful tool for the film production community. [Photography]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To IVAN KRUGLAK for his commitment to the development of a wireless transmission system for video-assisted images for the motion picture industry. Through years of persistent effort
column6: Mr. Kruglak has commercialized and popularized a technique of great utility for motion picture camera operations. By introducing diversity antennas and a time code insertion accessory
column7: he has optimized camera wireless video-assist components. [Camera]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To DR. DOUGLAS R. ROBLE for his contribution to tracking technology and for the design and implementation of the TRACK system for camera position calculation and scene reconstruction. The TRACK system is an integrated software tool that uses computer-vision techniques to extract critical 2D and 3D information about a scene and the camera used to film it. [Special Photographic]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To THADDEUS BEIER for the design and implementation of ras_track
column6: a system for 2D tracking
column7: stabilization
column8: and 3D camera and object tracking. Ras_track allows the user to determine the postiton and location of the camera and objects in a scene by tracking points in a scanned sequence. [Special Photographic]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To MANFRED N. KLEMME and DONALD E. WETZEL for the design and development of the K-Tek Microphone Boom Pole and accessories for on-set motion picture sound recording. The K-TEK series microphone boom pole provides production recording personnel with a self-lubricated
column6: light-weight
column7: sturdy pole with multiple accessories. [Sound]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To NICK FOSTER for his software development in the field of water simulation systems. This software technique provides an efficient and flexible method for the creation of flowing streams
column6: oceans
column7: tidal waves and turbulence for motion picture visual effects. [Special Photographic]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To CARY PHILLIPS for the design and development of the ‘Caricature’ Animation System at Industrial Light & Magic. By integrating existing tools into a powerful interactive system
column6: and adding an expressive multi-target shape interpolation-based freeform animation system
column7: the ‘Caricature’ system provides a degree of subtlety and refinement not possible with other systems. [Special Photographic]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To DR. MITCHELL J. BOGDANOWICZ of the Eastman Kodak Company
column6: and JIM MEYER and STAN MILLER of Rosco Laboratories
column7: Inc. for the design of the CalColor Calibrated Color Effects Filters. Designed to correspond to the spectral sensitivity of color negative film stocks
column8: these filters provide for improved color control in motion picture lighting. [Lenses and Filters]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
column6: RICHARD C. SEHLIN
column7: DR. CARL F. HOLTZ and DAVID F. KOPPERL of the Eastman Kodak Company for the research and development of the concept of molecular sieves applied to improve the archival properties of processed photographic film. The use of zeolite crystals as molecular sieves to absorb moisture
column8: acetic acid
column9: methylene chloride and a variety of solvents created an effective deterrent to the effects of vinegar syndrome in stored film stock. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To TAKUO MIYAGISHIMA and ALBERT K. SAIKI of Panavision
column6: Inc. for the design and development of the Eyepiece Leveler. This leveler keeps the camera eyepiece at the same level
column7: regardless of whether the camera position is tilted up or down
column8: enabling the camera operator to concentrate on the composition of the image. [Camera]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To EDMUND M. DI GIULIO and JAMES BARTELL of Cinema Products for the design of the KeyKode Sync Reader. The KeyKode Sync Reader provides a fast
column6: accurate and user-friendly means of utilizing the KeyKode information on film
column7: thereby expediting the editorial and post-production processes. [Laboratory]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To IVAN KRUGLAK for his pioneering concept and the development of the Coherent Time Code Slate. Time code slates have had significant impact on the filmmaking process by simplifying post-production. This development makes the synchronization process faster and more precise
column6: particularly when multiple cameras are used. [Editorial and Pre-production]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To MIKE DENECKE for refining and further developing electronic time code slates. Due to their features and simplified operational procedures
column6: the Denecke slates have had significant impact on the motion picture industry and have become the standard for electronic time code slates. [Editorial and Pre-production]"

Category: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL AWARD (Technical Achievement Award)
Subkey: To ED ZWANEVELD and FREDERICK GASOI of the National Film Board of Canada
column6: and MIKE LAZARIDIS and DALE BRUBACHER-CRESSMAN of Research in Motion for the design and development of the DigiSync Film KeyKode Reader. The DigiSync Film KeyKode Reader provides a fast
column7: accurate and user-friendly means of utilizing the KeyKode information on film
column8: expediting the editorial and post-production processes. [Laboratory]"
